results.title: Bitter sweet
results.creator_credit: W S. Van Dyke, Victor Saville and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: On the eve of her wedding to a priggish Londoner, a Victorian girl and her dashing music teacher elope to Vienna, where he hopes to sell his music. Cast includes Jeanette MacDonald, Nelson Eddy, George Sanders. Original play, music and lyrics by Noel Coward.

results.title: Bitter sweet
results.creator_credit: Herbert Wilcox, United Artists Corporation and British and Dominions Films
results.brief_description: Based on Noel Coward’s operetta, this is the first version of “Bitter sweet” (later Hollywood version in 1940 starring Nelson Eddy/Jeanette MacDonald) featuring Anna Neagle, Fernand Graavey and Esme Percy. It tells the romantic tale of a now older Sarah reminiscing about her younger days and her first love Carl, a musician. Charming and melodic, this bitter sweet love story is beautifully filmed by prolific British director and producer, Herbert Wilcox (Nell Gwyn, No No Nanette, The Lady with a Lamp to name a few) assisted by the wonderful dialogue, lyrics and music of Noel Coward. NB: Sound quality is muffled.

results.title: Bitter Springs
results.creator_credit: Ralph Smart, Sir Michael Balcon and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description: The year is 1900 and sheepfarmer Wally King is given the rights to territory in the Australian outback. He sets out with his family to claim the land, but having made the hazardous 600 mile journey through wilderness, they find that the “permanent water” - Bitter Springs - is home to a tribe of aborigines who will not move away. A violent struggle develops between tribesmen and the white settlers which can only be resolved when the white man’s gun is replaced by compromise. For its time, this film was notably liberal in balancing the point of view of encroaching European settlers with Aboriginal claims for land rights. Starring Tommy Trinder, Chips Rafferty, Gordon Jackson, Jean Blue, Michael Pate, Charles Tingwell, Nonnie Piper, Nicky Yardley and Henry Murdock.

results.title: Bitter Herbs and Honey
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Amber Films
results.brief_description: Australian documentary focuses on the lives of European Jews who settled in the Melbourne suburb of Carlton in the 1940s, fleeing World War II atrocities and post-War conditions. Interestingly the Jews from Eastern Europe clashed with Anglo-Jews, settled in the nineteenth century, who identified as British rather than Jewish and disapproved of the too obvious presence of Sephardic Jews, with whom they feared association. Despite these and other difficulties, social groups thrived in the suburb, where people shared life, food, religion and a common experience. Local residents from the period, many recalling their childhood, discuss a marvellously rich and joyous, if impoverished, family life; others talk about the racism suffered at school and in the street; several recount the pain of being a Holocaust survivor and the trials of assimilation. Includes archival footage from the era interspersed with recreations and a slew of interviews that include: Pinchus Ringelblum, Hilary Rubinstein, Bernard Rechter, Solomon Pose, Victor Smorgon, Arnord Zable, Jean Holkner, June Factor, Freydi Mrocki, Sam Lipski, Amirah Inglis, Rachel Levita and Miriam Kuna. Features some marvellous Yiddish songs and several interviewees discuss their parents yearning to sustain the use of Yiddish language. With occasional English subtitles.

results.title: Bits and bytes. Parts 1-12
results.creator_credit: Stuart Beecroft, David Stansfield, Denise Boiteau, TV Ontario and Time-Life Video
results.brief_description: Part 1. ‘Getting started’. Part 2. “Ready made programs’. Part 3. ‘How programs work’. Part 4. ‘Storing information’. Part 5. ‘Communication between computers’. Part 6.’Computer languages’. Part 7. ‘Computer assisted instruction’. Part 8. ‘Learning objectives’. Part 9. ‘Computer Graphics’. Part 10 ‘Computer music’. Part 11. ‘Computers at work’. Part 12 ‘What next’. Based on the Apple II series computer, and IBM, there are sound basic explanations about basic computer functions and programs.

results.title: Birth of the Bomb (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This is the background story of the making of the first atomic bomb. The period covered is from 1938 to the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima in 1945. German efforts to create an atomic bomb are described. the intensive research into the development of the bomb in the US is dealt with extensively. Includes archival film and interviews with some of those involved.

results.title: Birth control - How?
results.creator_credit: Frank Slinglarn, Stuart Schulberg, Ted Yates and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Discusses “the pill” and other birth control methods, and describes controlled experiment groups in Kentucky and in Puerto Rico. Examines some of the moral dimensions of birth control.

results.title: Birdlovers of New South Wales: the story of the Gould League
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of the foundation and growth of the Gould League of Birdlovers, who study, watch and protect native birds. Photography by Harry Malcolm with majority of bird shots by Norman Chaffer. Commentary by David Low.

results.title: Biquefarre
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, William Gilcher, Marie-Francoise Mascaro and Bertrand van Effenterre
results.brief_description:
Georges Rouquier revisits the characters of his 1938 ‘Biquefarre’ 35 year later. The family whose farm was wired for electricity in the first film are still on the family spread in 1983. The plot revolves around Raoul who decides to sell the farm to take up a job as gardener with the City of Toulouse. Though documentary in technique, the film is well planned and scripted, with its amateur cast convincingly mouthing the lines given them by Rouqier.

Credits: Producer, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, William Gilcher ; director, Georges Rouquier ; writers, Georges Rouquier, Maria Signorini ; photography, Andre Villard ; music, Yves Gilbert
Cast: Henri Rouquier, Maria Rouquier, Roger Malet, Roch Rouquier, Raymond Rouquier.

results.title: Bing bang boom
results.creator_credit: Joan Henson, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A novel way of discovering music without instruments, in a Grade 7 classroom. Innovator and Toronto composer R. Murray Shafer is teacher for a day. His purpose is to show children that music is more than painfully learned notes and scales. He has the class listen to every sound around them and then harmonize and orchestrate what they hear - their voices, hands, feet - into a rhythmic musical pattern. The result is a hit, and a convincing illustration that children learn best when it’s from the inside out. Awards: American Film Festival; Sydney.
